SHOCKING!
Modi Govt used â‚¹1751 crores of public money to enrich an American company for Modi's PR:
During his US visit, Modi signed a deal with the firm Micron for establishing a facility in Gujarat
The deal is worth $2.7 bn i.e. â‚¹2274 crores
But here's the catch  The Micron deal is merely for assembling & testing semiconductor chips
 Assembling requires ZERO technological knowledge or transfer. It contributes NOTHING to India's semiconductor vision
 Micron benefits from cheap Indian labor & reduces its China exposure
But Modi Govt has shockingly subsidized & enriched Micron from public money:
 Of the â‚¹2274 crore deal, govt will contribute 70% i.e. â‚¹1571 crores
 Micron will contribute 30% i.e. ONLY â‚¹682 crores
And yet, Micron will OWN 100% of the plant with ZERO govt stake.Therefore,
 Micron gets to reduce its chip assembly costs & its business risk from China. This allows Micron to make extra millions in profit
 India gets to ONLY assemble the chips i.e. no technology transfer & no specialized knowledge
Who benefits: ONLY Micron. Despite investing 70% i.e. â‚¹1571 crores of public money, India will get ZERO stake in the Micron plant
 Micron gets 100% of an Indian plant worth â‚¹2274 crore ONLY by paying â‚¹682 crore
Why is the Indian exchequer losing â‚¹1571 crores to favor a private US company?Contrary to claims by Min @AshwiniVaishnaw, this plant does NOT benefit India's knowledge of semiconductor design or manufacturing.
It only outsources assembling of chips with no technological/design know-how.
Modi Govt WASTED â‚¹1571 crores purely for Modi's foreign PR
For more details, check out this insightful article by Prabir Purkayastha of @newsclickin in @asiatimesonline:

A bitter truth from Modi's US visit.

India's Micron deal follows a curious business model...

India will pay 70% of the cost but Micron will own 100% of the plant.

The total cost of setting up the Micron plant in Gujarat is $2.75 billion with both the central and state government providing for 70% of the cost and the remaining 30% or $825 million will be provided by Micron.
